elements.content: In the field of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), one of the challenges is the fabrication of novel materials that display/correlate the prediction of structures and functionality. Usually, the structures of MOFs are influenced by the skeleton of ligands. In this article, five different dicarboxylic acids, namely, fumaric dioic acid (H2FUM), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (2-H2ATA), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NAPDC), 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2BDC), and oxalic acid (H2OX) are employed as the secondary auxiliary ligands to perform a systematic study on the structure diversities in the Zn(II)–1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) frameworks. By introducing various secondary dicarboxylate anions in the Zn(II)-L system, six new complexes {Zn(L)(FUM)}∞ (1), {Zn2(L)(2-ATA)2}∞ (2), {Zn(L)(1,4-NAPDC)·H2O}∞ (3), {Zn2(L)(1,4-NAPDC)2·2DMF}∞ (4), {Zn(L)(1,2-BDC)}∞ (5), and {Zn3(L)2(OX)3·H2O}∞ (6) were obtained. Complexes 1 and 3 possess three-dimensional (3D) 5-fold interpenetrating diamond frameworks. Complex 2 is a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating α-Po framework constructed by dinucear {Zn2} secondary building units (SBUs). Complex 4 exhibits a 3D 2-fold interpenetrating α-Po framework when DMF acts as the reaction solvent. Complex 5 shows a 3D framework with diamondoid topology, which includes L/Zn(II)/L helical chains. Complex 6 presents an interesting 3D structure constructed from {Zn(II)-OX-Zn(II)} rod-shaped SBUs and L ligands as pillars. The diverse structures of these six complexes indicate that the skeleton of dicarboxylate anions plays a great role in the assembly of such different frameworks. Moreover, the fluorescence properties of the complexes 1–6 were investigated in the solid state.

elements.content: Six new entangled Zn(II)−1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) frameworks of 1−6 have been successfully synthesized by hydro/solvethermal methods assisted with various auxiliary O-donor dicarboxylate ligands. These results demonstrated that the entangled Zn(II)−1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene system can be modulated by choosing different secondary ligands.
elements.clean_text: Six new entangled Zn(II)-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) frameworks of 1-6 have been successfully synthesized by hydro/solvethermal methods assisted with various auxiliary O-donor dicarboxylate ligands. These results demonstrated that the entangled Zn(II)-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene system can be modulated by choosing different secondary ligands.

elements.content: Considerable attention given to metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from not only their intrinsic aesthetics beauty but also their potential applications in nanoscale magnetism, molecular separation, chiral catalysis, gas storage and capture, and drug delivery. From a synthetic point of view, the judicious selection of appropriate organic ligands is proved to be one of the most effective ways to manipulate the versatile structures of MOFs. Among multitudinous organic ligands, imidazole-containing ligands, in particular, have proven to be good candidates for the construction of novel MOFs due to their flexible and diverse coordination modes. To date, a large number of MOFs based on these ligands have been constructed. According to previous literature, most of them are based on flexible or tridentate, even multidentate, imidazole-containing ligands; MOFs constructed from rigid bidentate 1,4-bis(1-imidazolyl) benzene (L) ligands are relatively scarce. The results of our previous studies show that this rigid neutral bis(imidazole) ligand exhibits the special ability to coordinate to various metal centers in two typical coordination fashions (cis-configuration and trans-configuration) through bond rotation of the terminal imidazolyl rings. However, the organic polycarboxylic acids ligands, which are the most efficient organic ligands to connect different metal ions, including main-group metals, transition metals, and rare-earth metals, have been extensively employed to construct MOFs with diversity structures. Remarkably, the reported rational fabrication of MOFs mainly focused on metal–carboxylate systems with structural modulation by N-donor derivatives as secondary auxiliary ligands. However, up to now the systematic studies concerned with the mediation of the structures of the N-donor–metal system by different carboxylate ligands have not been well investigated. In addition, a careful selection of the different properties of carboxylates as secondary auxiliary ligands, such as shape, functionality, flexibility, angle, and symmetry, is a key step for the rational design of structures with specific physical and chemical properties. Also in our previous studies, we have investigated the effect of the ligand skeleton on modulating porosity and the degree of interpenetration. We find that terminal groups and ligand spacers play significant roles in determining the degree of interpenetration in MOFs. In order to extend our previous work and explore the influence of dicarboxylic acid ligand skeletons (including rigid dicarboxylic acid, flexible dicarboxylic acid, and dicarboxylic acid bearing noncoordinating groups) on the structures of the metal-L frameworks, five dicarboxylic acids ligands, namely, fumaric dioic acid (H2FUM), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (2-H2ATA), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NAPDC), 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2BDC), and oxalic acid (H2OX), are employed as auxiliary ligands (Chart ). In this article, six new Zn(II) MOFs, {Zn(L)(FUM)}∞ (1), {Zn2(L)(2-ATA)2}∞ (2), {Zn(L)(1,4-NAPDC)·H2O}∞ (3), {Zn2(L)(1,4-NAPDC)2·2DMF}∞ (4), {Zn(L)(1,2-BDC)}∞ (5), and {Zn3(L)2(OX)3·H2O}∞ (6), have been obtained through the introduction of the above five dicarboxylic acids ligands into Zn(II)–1,4-Bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene frameworks. On the basis of synthesis and structural characterization, the relationships between complexes frameworks and ligands are discussed. The results provide an indication that dicarboxylic acid ligand skeletons have great influence on the interpenetrating degree of MOFs structures. Meanwhile, we discovered that solvent and temperature have significant effect on the formation of complexes 3 and 4. The fluorescence properties of the complexes 1–6 have been also investigated in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Considerable attention given to metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from not only their intrinsic aesthetics beauty but also their potential applications in nanoscale magnetism, molecular separation, chiral catalysis, gas storage and capture, and drug delivery. From a synthetic point of view, the judicious selection of appropriate organic ligands is proved to be one of the most effective ways to manipulate the versatile structures of MOFs. Among multitudinous organic ligands, imidazole-containing ligands, in particular, have proven to be good candidates for the construction of novel MOFs due to their flexible and diverse coordination modes. To date, a large number of MOFs based on these ligands have been constructed. According to previous literature, most of them are based on flexible or tridentate, even multidentate, imidazole-containing ligands; MOFs constructed from rigid bidentate 1,4-bis(1-imidazolyl) benzene (L) ligands are relatively scarce. The results of our previous studies show that this rigid neutral bis(imidazole) ligand exhibits the special ability to coordinate to various metal centers in two typical coordination fashions (cis-configuration and trans-configuration) through bond rotation of the terminal imidazolyl rings. However, the organic polycarboxylic acids ligands, which are the most efficient organic ligands to connect different metal ions, including main-group metals, transition metals, and rare-earth metals, have been extensively employed to construct MOFs with diversity structures. Remarkably, the reported rational fabrication of MOFs mainly focused on metal-carboxylate systems with structural modulation by N-donor derivatives as secondary auxiliary ligands. However, up to now the systematic studies concerned with the mediation of the structures of the N-donor-metal system by different carboxylate ligands have not been well investigated. In addition, a careful selection of the different properties of carboxylates as secondary auxiliary ligands, such as shape, functionality, flexibility, angle, and symmetry, is a key step for the rational design of structures with specific physical and chemical properties. Also in our previous studies, we have investigated the effect of the ligand skeleton on modulating porosity and the degree of interpenetration. We find that terminal groups and ligand spacers play significant roles in determining the degree of interpenetration in MOFs. In order to extend our previous work and explore the influence of dicarboxylic acid ligand skeletons (including rigid dicarboxylic acid, flexible dicarboxylic acid, and dicarboxylic acid bearing noncoordinating groups) on the structures of the metal-L frameworks, five dicarboxylic acids ligands, namely, fumaric dioic acid (H2FUM), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (2-H2ATA), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NAPDC), 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2BDC), and oxalic acid (H2OX), are employed as auxiliary ligands (Chart ). In this article, six new Zn(II) MOFs, {Zn(L)(FUM)}∞ (1), {Zn2(L)(2-ATA)2}∞ (2), {Zn(L)(1,4-NAPDC)⋅H2O}∞ (3), {Zn2(L)(1,4-NAPDC)2⋅2DMF}∞ (4), {Zn(L)(1,2-BDC)}∞ (5), and {Zn3(L)2(OX)3⋅H2O}∞ (6), have been obtained through the introduction of the above five dicarboxylic acids ligands into Zn(II)-1,4-Bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene frameworks. On the basis of synthesis and structural characterization, the relationships between complexes frameworks and ligands are discussed. The results provide an indication that dicarboxylic acid ligand skeletons have great influence on the interpenetrating degree of MOFs structures. Meanwhile, we discovered that solvent and temperature have significant effect on the formation of complexes 3 and 4. The fluorescence properties of the complexes 1-6 have been also investigated in the solid state.

elements.content: All of the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available and used as received. The ligand 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) was synthesized according to the literature procedure. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Fluorescence spectra were performed on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

Materials and General Methods

All of the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available and used as received. The ligand 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) was synthesized according to the literature procedure. Elemental analysis of C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Fluorescence spectra were performed on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148 mg), NaOH (1 mmol, 40 mg), H2FUM (0.5 mmol, 58 mg), and L (0.5 mmol, 105 mg) in 15 mL of the component solvent (H2O/CH3OH = 2:1) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 160 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h–1, colorless block crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. The mother liquid was decanted, and the crystals were rinsed three times with ethanol (8 mL × 3) and dried in air for 2 h. Yield: ∼35% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C16H12N4O4Zn: C, 49.27; H, 3.10; N, 14.37%. Found: C, 49.50; H, 3.33; N, 14.21%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3470 m, 3154w, 1618s, 1464s, 1359s, 1236 m, 1182 m, 1131s, 1068s, 961w, 881s, 848s, 798w, 729 m, 652s.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data of 1–6 were collected on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All of the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms excluded in conterions were located in successive difference Fourier synthesis and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The crystal data and structure refinement details for complexes 1–6 are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determinations

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data of 1-6 were collected on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All of the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms excluded in conterions were located in successive difference Fourier synthesis and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. The crystal data and structure refinement details for complexes 1-6 are given in Table .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and exhibits an interesting 5-fold interpenetrated 3D framework based on a diamondoid topology. In the asymmetric unit of 1, there is one Zn center, one L ligand, and one FUM2– ligand. As shown in Figure a, the Zn center exhibits a tetra-coordinated environment with two nitrogen atoms deriving from two different imidazolyl of L ligands and two oxygen atoms originating from two different FUM2– ligands. The lengths of Zn–O bonds are 1.975 (2) Å, and those of Zn–N bonds are 2.041 (3) Å (Figure a). Moreover, two completely deprotonated carboxylate groups of FUM2– both adopt the monodentate coordination modes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Structure Description of {Zn(L)(FUM)}∞ (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and exhibits an interesting 5-fold interpenetrated 3D framework based on a diamondoid topology. In the asymmetric unit of 1, there is one Zn center, one L ligand, and one FUM2- ligand. As shown in Figure a, the Zn center exhibits a tetra-coordinated environment with two nitrogen atoms deriving from two different imidazolyl of L ligands and two oxygen atoms originating from two different FUM2- ligands. The lengths of Zn-O bonds are 1.975 (2) Å, and those of Zn-N bonds are 2.041 (3) Å (Figure a). Moreover, two completely deprotonated carboxylate groups of FUM2- both adopt the monodentate coordination modes.

elements.content: View of (a) the coordination environment of Zn(II) in 1 (the hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity); (b) the single adamantanoid cage and topology in 1; and (c) the 5-fold interpenetrated diamond framework for 1 (individual networks are displayed in different colors).
elements.clean_text: 1  View of (a) the coordination environment of Zn(II) in 1 (the hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity); (b) the single adamantanoid cage and topology in 1; and (c) the 5-fold interpenetrated diamond framework for 1 (individual networks are displayed in different colors).

elements.content: The topological analysis of complex 1 reveals that it is a typical diamond framework containing cyclohexane-like chair conformations (Figure b). In complex 1, the FUM2– anions only exhibit one coordination mode (bridging bis(monodentate)). Thus, each Zn(II) ion is connected to the other four Zn(II) ions by six FUM2– anions and six L ligands, and in the formation of a single adamantanoid cage with four adamantoid type windows. Compared with compound 3, the Zn···Zn separations observed in 1 among each network are in the range of 9.3425–13.7207 Å. Moreover, there were no free solvent molecules occupying the void space in complex 1. Generally, the large amount of empty space within framework of complex allows for mutual interpenetration. As a result, the potential voids in 1 are filled via mutual interpenetration of four independent equivalent frameworks, leading to a 5-fold interpenetrated diamond net (Figure c). Although many diamond-related nets displaying various interpenetration modes ranging from 2- to 11-fold have been reported, the 5-fold interpenetrating diamond frameworks that are obtained by reacting with mixed organic dicarboxylic acid ligands bearing different skeletons in the presence of 1,4- bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene are relatively few.

elements.content: Structure analysis reveals that 2 is a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D framework constructed of dimetal {Zn2} units and two types of organic ligands (L and 2-ATA2–). elements.content: In 2, the 2-ATA2– ligands with the different coordination modes bridge dimetal {Zn2} units to form an infinite 2D 4(4) network. Furthermore, the N-donor L ligands as pillars take a μ2-bidentate coordination mode to extend the 2D nets to be the 3D structure. In order to better understand the final architecture of the complex, the framework of 2 can be abstracted as a uninodal 6-connected network from the topological approach. As illustrated in Figure b, the {Zn2O6N2} cluster can be viewed as a six-connected node connected by four 2-ATA2– ligands and two L ligands. So, each {Zn2O6N2} cluster is linked to six other dimetal centers, resulting in the formation of a cubic framework (Figure c). The short Schläfli symbol is {41263}. Moreover, there are large rectangular windows (11.19 × 16.37 Å) in 2. Thus, in order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework, the potential voids cavities are filled by the other two identical networks, resulting in a 3-fold interpenetrating network (Figure d).

elements.content: We can consider each L ligand and 1,4-NAPDC2– anion to be one connecting rod. So each Zn(II) is linked to four different Zn(II) ions, resulting in the formation of an adamantoid type cage unit (Figure b). The 3D network of 3 is a diamondoid framework accomplished by the cage units. In complex 3, there were solvent molecules occupying part of the void space, and another part of the potential voids are filled via mutual interpenetration of four independent equivalent frameworks, that is, the final structure of 3 is a 5-fold interpenetrated diamond net similar to complex 1 (Figure c). The Zn···Zn separations observed among each network in the range of 11.1093–13.6316 Å, while the Zn···Zn···Zn angles are in the range of 92.269–125.644°, which represents a significant distortion from the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5° found in diamond. Compared with 1, the Zn···Zn separations in distances and Zn···Zn···Zn angles are vastly different, may be due to different lengths and the skeleton of the FUM2– and 1,4-NAPDC2– ligands.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121. The geometry of the Zn(II) ion is found to be a tetrahedron held in the {Zn2N2O6} dinuclear unit, each Zn(II) ion supplied by three oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups of two unique 1,4-NAPDC2– anions with normal Zn–O distances from 1.943(2) to 1.989(2) Å and one nitrogen atom of the L ligand (Zn–N, 1.977(2) Å), as illustrated in Figure a. It is noteworthy that there are different coordination types of 1,4-NAPDC2– anions different from 3, namely, bridging bis(monodentate) and bridging bis(dimonodentate). Two Zn(II) ions are bridged by a pair of 1,4-NAPDC2– μ2-carboxylate ends into a dinuclear {Zn2N2O6} unit; the intradimer Zn–Zn distance is 3.653 Å.

elements.content: Compared with aforementioned complexes, each L also acts as a bis(dimonodentate) ligand, while the left- and right-handed helical chains come into being where two Zn(II) ions and one L ligand are connected in a L/Zn(II)/L fashion (Figure b). In addition, each 1,2-BDC2– acts as a bridging ligand coordinating to two Zn(II) ions and linking neighboring L/Zn(II)/L helical chains into a 2D layer. Finally, complex 5 was extended into a 3D framework assembled by L and 1,2-BDC2– ligands. Furthermore, the Zn(II) center could be viewed as a 4-connected node, which is connected to four other Zn(II) ions made up of tetrahedron geometry. As a result, the 3D framework of 5 can be simplified as a uninodal 4-connected topology with the short symbol of {66} (Figure c).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the space group of complex 6 is the same as 1 in monoclinic space group C 2/c. To evaluate the effect of length of the dicarboxylate ligand on the framework formation of complex, we employed the shortest H2OX among aliphatic series dicarboxylic acids to react with Zn(II) ions in the presence of the same N-donor L ligands. For 6, Zn(II) ions have two types of coordination modes and were found to be both six coordination, one of the modes is that the Zn(II) ion is surrounded by two N atoms from two imidazolyl rings of two distinct L and four chelating O atoms from two OX2– anions; the other is coordinated to six chelating O atoms from three OX2– anions (Figure a). In addition, there is one uncoordinated water molecule residing in the interspaces of 6.

elements.content: The structural differences of complexes 1–6 have demonstrated that the series of different dicarboxylate ligands are critical factors in the formation of such coordination architectures, and previous reports have mentioned the role of organic carboxylate anions. In this work, five dicarboxylate ligands have different size and flexibility, and two of them bear noncoordinating groups. The selection of organic carboxylate anions can mediate or even satisfy the coordination needs of the metal center and eventually generate more meaningful architectures. In other words, these factors contribute to diverse coordination polymers in the presence of 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) in our work. The framework of complex 3 exhibits an interpenetration degree similar to that of 1 (5-fold interpenetrating diamond network), although 1,4-NAPDC2– bears a longer benzene ring group instead of the shorter FUM2–. This is because noncoordinating benzene ring groups in 1,4-NAPDC2– can partly inhibit the formation of large channels and thus decrease the possibility of more multiple interpenetration. But when we use another dicarboxylate 2-ATA2– bearing different noncoordinating groups (amino group) in 2 instead of phenyl group in 3, we can get different interpenetrating degrees in complex 2. The reduction of the interpenetration degree in 2 compared with that in 3 is mainly because of the synergistic effect of the amino groups and the dinuclear {Zn2O6N2} clusters as vertices that can both occupy a certain space and release less capacity. In order to investigate the influence of the distances and angles of two carboxyl groups and semirigid skeletons of dicarboxylates on the assembly of complexes, we introduced auxiliary ligands 1,2-H2BDC in 5 and H2OX in 6. As a result, two noninterpenetrating networks were obtained. Most different from FUM2–, the 1,2-BDC2– and OX2– have different skeletons, possess different steric hindrance, and at the same time bear 180° and 60° angles, respectively. Furthermore, the distance of two carboxyly groups in FUM2– is relatively longer than that of in 1,2-BDC2– and OX2–. However, the semirigid skeleton in OX2– has more flexibility compared with that of 1,2-BDC2–, so we obtained the different 3D noninterpenetrating networks in 5 and 6. For complexes 3 and 4, when the solvents in 3 (H2O/CH3OH = 2:1) were changed to DMF in 4 and the temperature was adjusted from 160 to 100 °C, two different interpenetrated frameworks were successfully separated. Complex 3 exhibits a five-interpenetrating diamond network, while complex 4 is a two-interpenetrating α-Po topology network. Thus, the results imply that temperature and solvents also play important roles in constructing different degrees of interpenetrated networks.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Organic Dicarboxylates on the Structures of the Complexes

The structural differences of complexes 1-6 have demonstrated that the series of different dicarboxylate ligands are critical factors in the formation of such coordination architectures, and previous reports have mentioned the role of organic carboxylate anions. In this work, five dicarboxylate ligands have different size and flexibility, and two of them bear noncoordinating groups. The selection of organic carboxylate anions can mediate or even satisfy the coordination needs of the metal center and eventually generate more meaningful architectures. In other words, these factors contribute to diverse coordination polymers in the presence of 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) in our work. The framework of complex 3 exhibits an interpenetration degree similar to that of 1 (5-fold interpenetrating diamond network), although 1,4-NAPDC2- bears a longer benzene ring group instead of the shorter FUM2-. This is because noncoordinating benzene ring groups in 1,4-NAPDC2- can partly inhibit the formation of large channels and thus decrease the possibility of more multiple interpenetration. But when we use another dicarboxylate 2-ATA2- bearing different noncoordinating groups (amino group) in 2 instead of phenyl group in 3, we can get different interpenetrating degrees in complex 2. The reduction of the interpenetration degree in 2 compared with that in 3 is mainly because of the synergistic effect of the amino groups and the dinuclear {Zn2O6N2} clusters as vertices that can both occupy a certain space and release less capacity. In order to investigate the influence of the distances and angles of two carboxyl groups and semirigid skeletons of dicarboxylates on the assembly of complexes, we introduced auxiliary ligands 1,2-H2BDC in 5 and H2OX in 6. As a result, two noninterpenetrating networks were obtained. Most different from FUM2-, the 1,2-BDC2- and OX2- have different skeletons, possess different steric hindrance, and at the same time bear 180° and 60° angles, respectively. Furthermore, the distance of two carboxyly groups in FUM2- is relatively longer than that of in 1,2-BDC2- and OX2-. However, the semirigid skeleton in OX2- has more flexibility compared with that of 1,2-BDC2-, so we obtained the different 3D noninterpenetrating networks in 5 and 6. For complexes 3 and 4, when the solvents in 3 (H2O/CH3OH = 2:1) were changed to DMF in 4 and the temperature was adjusted from 160 to 100 °C, two different interpenetrated frameworks were successfully separated. Complex 3 exhibits a five-interpenetrating diamond network, while complex 4 is a two-interpenetrating α-Po topology network. Thus, the results imply that temperature and solvents also play important roles in constructing different degrees of interpenetrated networks.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of compounds 1–6 and the L ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes 1–6 are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. Compared with free L, the enhancement of fluorescence intensity in the complexes is probably due to the unique coordination of L to the Zn(II) center, increasing the conformational rigidity of the ligand, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π–π*) excited state. As depicted in Figure, complexes 1–6 exhibit fluorescent emission with the maxima at 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 2, 440 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 3, 418 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, 441 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 5, and 427 nm (λex = 375 nm) for 6. Such fluorescence behavior may be attributed to the intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the free L ligand. The red- or blue-shifted emissions of 1–6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π*–n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescence emission of complexes 1–6 in the presence of the N-donor ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The luminescent properties of compounds 1-6 and the L ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes 1-6 are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. Compared with free L, the enhancement of fluorescence intensity in the complexes is probably due to the unique coordination of L to the Zn(II) center, increasing the conformational rigidity of the ligand, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π-π*) excited state. As depicted in Figure, complexes 1-6 exhibit fluorescent emission with the maxima at 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 2, 440 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 3, 418 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, 441 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 5, and 427 nm (λex = 375 nm) for 6. Such fluorescence behavior may be attributed to the intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the free L ligand. The red- or blue-shifted emissions of 1-6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π*-n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescence emission of complexes 1-6 in the presence of the N-donor ligand.

elements.content: Six new entangled Zn(II)–1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) frameworks of 1–6 have been successfully synthesized by hydro/solvethermal methods assisted with various auxiliary O-donor dicarboxylate ligands. These results demonstrate that the entangled Zn(II)–1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene topological system can be modulated by choosing different secondary ligands. Moreover, the temperature and solvent can also influence the interpenetrating degree of the complexes. This work provides a new paradigm for further rational design and synthesis of new entangled metal–organic frameworks via the control of auxiliary ligands. The purple emission of these compounds suggests that they may be potential candidates for purple-light-emitting materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Six new entangled Zn(II)-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L) frameworks of 1-6 have been successfully synthesized by hydro/solvethermal methods assisted with various auxiliary O-donor dicarboxylate ligands. These results demonstrate that the entangled Zn(II)-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene topological system can be modulated by choosing different secondary ligands. Moreover, the temperature and solvent can also influence the interpenetrating degree of the complexes. This work provides a new paradigm for further rational design and synthesis of new entangled metal-organic frameworks via the control of auxiliary ligands. The purple emission of these compounds suggests that they may be potential candidates for purple-light-emitting materials.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 148 mg), NaOH (1 mmol, 40 mg), H2FUM (0.5 mmol, 58 mg), and L (0.5 mmol, 105 mg) in 15 mL of the component solvent (H2O/CH3OH = 2:1) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 160 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h–1, colorless block crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. The mother liquid was decanted, and the crystals were rinsed three times with ethanol (8 mL × 3) and dried in air for 2 h. Yield: ∼35% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C16H12N4O4Zn: C, 49.27; H, 3.10; N, 14.37%. Found: C, 49.50; H, 3.33; N, 14.21%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3470 m, 3154w, 1618s, 1464s, 1359s, 1236 m, 1182 m, 1131s, 1068s, 961w, 881s, 848s, 798w, 729 m, 652s.

{Zn<sub>2</sub>(L)(2-ATA)<sub>2</sub>}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that 2-H2ATA (0.5 mmol, 90 mg) was used instead of H2FUM. Yield: ∼30% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C14H10N3O4Zn: C, 48.09; H, 3.09; N, 12.02%. Found: C, 48.35; H, 3.43; N, 12.52%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3444w, 3155w, 3140w, 3129 m, 1563w, 1529 m, 1375 m, 1262s, 1137 m, 1070s, 962s, 839s, 777s, 649s, 588w, 544w.

{Zn(L)(1,4-NAPDC)·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Synthesis of 3 was similar to that of 1 except that 1,4-H2NAPDC (0.5 mmol, 108 mg) was used instead of H2FUM. Yield: ∼40% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C24H18N4O5Zn: C, 56.76; H, 3.57; N, 11.03%. Found: C, 56.01; H, 3.11; N, 10.84%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3153 m, 2360 m, 1605s, 1531s, 1458 m, 1399s, 1356s, 1257s, 1136 m, 1066s, 962s, 835s, 756 m, 651 m, 583 m, 489w.

{Zn<sub>2</sub>(L)(1,4-NAPDC)<sub>2</sub>·2DMF}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Synthesis of 4 was in a Teflon-lined autoclave in DMF (5 mL), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol, 29.7 mg), and 1,4-H2NAPDC (0.1 mmol, 21.6 mg), and L (0.1 mmol, 21 mg) was added to the solvent and heated to 100 °C for 4 days. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h–1, colorless block crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained. The mother liquor was decanted and the crystals dried in air for 2 h. Yield: ∼30% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C42H36N6O10Zn2: C, 55.10; H, 3.96; N, 9.18%. Found: C, 54.55; H, 4.11; N, 9.31%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3137 m, 1667w, 1528s, 1457 m, 1407s, 1364s, 1267s, 1065s, 963s, 827s, 651s, 579 m, 454s.

{Zn(L)(1,2-BDC)}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

Synthesis of 5 was similar to that of 1 except that 1,2-H2BDC (0.5 mmol, 83 mg) was used instead of H2FUM, and the temperature was changed for 170 °C. Yield: ∼30% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C20H14N4O4Zn: C, 54.63; H, 3.21; N, 12.74%. Found: C, 54.28; H, 3.36; N, 13.09%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3124 m, 2362w, 1567 m, 1538 m, 1445s, 1383s, 1307 m, 1249s, 1143s, 1076s, 962s, 841s, 762s, 705 m, 658s, 528 m, 481 m, 422w.

{Zn<sub>3</sub>(L)<sub>2</sub>(OX)<sub>3</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O }<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

Synthesis of 6 was similar to that of 5 except that H2OX (0.5 mmol, 45 mg) was used instead of 1,2-H2BDC. Yield: ∼40% based on L. Elemental analysis, calcd for C30H22N8O13Zn3: C, 39.31; H, 2.63; N, 12.23%. Found: C, 39.54; H, 3.03; N, 11.95%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3415w, 3124w, 2362w, 1647s, 1601s, 1532s, 1315s, 1259 m, 1142 m, 1071s, 961s, 943 m, 838s, 804s, 736 m, 652s, 499w.

cln_elements.content: The luminescent properties of compounds 1–6 and the L ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes 1–6 are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. Compared with free L, the enhancement of fluorescence intensity in the complexes is probably due to the unique coordination of L to the Zn(II) center, increasing the conformational rigidity of the ligand, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π–π*) excited state. As depicted in Figure, complexes 1–6 exhibit fluorescent emission with the maxima at 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 2, 440 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 3, 418 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, 441 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 5, and 427 nm (λex = 375 nm) for 6. Such fluorescence behavior may be attributed to the intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the free L ligand. The red- or blue-shifted emissions of 1–6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π*–n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescence emission of complexes 1–6 in the presence of the N-donor ligand.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Properties

The luminescent properties of compounds 1-6 and the L ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Since complexes 1-6 are stable in air and insoluble in water or most organic solvents, no additional measurements in solution were performed. Compared with free L, the enhancement of fluorescence intensity in the complexes is probably due to the unique coordination of L to the Zn(II) center, increasing the conformational rigidity of the ligand, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π-π*) excited state. As depicted in Figure, complexes 1-6 exhibit fluorescent emission with the maxima at 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 2, 440 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 3, 418 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, 441 nm (λex = 395 nm) for 5, and 427 nm (λex = 375 nm) for 6. Such fluorescence behavior may be attributed to the intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the free L ligand. The red- or blue-shifted emissions of 1-6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π*-n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescence emission of complexes 1-6 in the presence of the N-donor ligand.
